revision.comment: /* Design Standards */
revision.text:
{{globalize|date=October 2012}} [[File:Mairie de Boinville-le-Gaillard 4.jpg|thumb|A wheelchair ramp in France]] A '''wheelchair ramp''' is an [[inclined plane]] installed in addition to or instead of [[stairway|stairs]]. Ramps permit [[wheelchair]] users, as well as people pushing [[stroller]]s, [[cart]]s, or other wheeled objects, to more easily access a building.
A wheelchair ramp can be permanent, semi-permanent or portable. Permanent ramps are designed to be bolted or otherwise attached in place. Semi-permanent ramps rest on top of the ground or concrete pad and are commonly used for the short term. Permanent and semi-permanent ramps are usually of aluminum, concrete or wood. Portable ramps are usually aluminum and typically fold for ease of transport. Portable ramps are primarily intended for home and building use but can also be used with vans to load an unoccupied mobility device or to load an occupied mobility device when both the device and the passenger are easy to handle.
Ramps must be carefully designed in order to be useful. In many places, laws dictate a ramp's minimum width and maximum slope. <ref name="ADA, 4052">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ada.gov/regs2010/2010ADAStandards/2010ADAstandards.htm#pgfId-1006877|title=2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design|date=September 15, 2010|publisher=US Department of Justice|section=405 Ramps}}</ref> <ref name="MA, ADA2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mobility-advisor.com/wheelchair-ramp-specs.html|title=ADA Wheelchair Ramp Specs|website=Mobility Advisor}}</ref>
In general, reduced incline rises are easier for wheelchair users to traverse and are safer in icy climates. However, they consume more space and require traveling a greater distance to go up. Hence, in some cases it is preferable to include an [[elevator]] or other type of [[wheelchair lift]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.handi-lift.com/articles/ramps-vs-lifts/|title=Ramps vs. Lifts {{!}} Handi-Lift|website=www.handi-lift.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-09}}</ref>
In many countries, wheelchair ramps and other features to facilitate [[Universal design|universal access]] are required by [[building code]] when constructing new facilities which are open to the public. Internationally, the [[United Nations]] [[Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities]] mandates nations take action to "enable persons with disabilities to live independently and participate fully in all aspects of life." Among other requirements, it compels countries to institute "minimum standards and guidelines..." for accessibility. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/development/desa/disabilities/convention-on-the-rights-of-persons-with-disabilities.html|title=Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD) {{!}} United Nations Enable|website=www.un.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-09}}</ref>
==Design Standards== In the U.S.A, the [[Americans with Disabilities Act]] (ADA) requires a [[Grade (slope)|slope]] of no more than 1:12 for wheelchairs and scooters for business and public use, which works out to {{convert|1|ft|mm|0}} of ramp for each {{convert|1|in|1|spell=in}} of rise. For example, a {{convert|20|in|adj=on}} rise requires a minimum of {{convert|20|ft|2}} in length of ramp. Additionally, ADA limits the longest single span of ramp, prior to a rest or turn platform, to {{convert|30|ft|2}}.<ref name="ADA, 405">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ada.gov/regs2010/2010ADAStandards/2010ADAstandards.htm#pgfId-1006877|title=2010 ADA Standards for Accessible Design|date=September 15, 2010|publisher=US Department of Justice|section=405 Ramps}}</ref><ref name="MA, ADA">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mobility-advisor.com/wheelchair-ramp-specs.html|title=ADA Wheelchair Ramp Specs|website=Mobility Advisor}}</ref>
Ramps can be as long as needed, but no single run of ramp can exceed {{convert|30|ft|2}}. Residential Applications usually are not required to meet ADA standards (ADA is a commercial code).
The UK's guidelines as recommended by the [[Disability Discrimination Act 1995]] and [[Equality Act 2010]] are a maximum of 1:12 for ramps (with exceptions for existing buildings) "Ramps should be as shallow as possible. The maximum permissible gradient is 1:12 [...], with the occasional exception in the case of short, steeper ramps when refitting existing buildings."<ref >{{cite web |url=http://www.basingstoke.gov.uk/NR/rdonlyres/C53C7118-21A1-4A25-896E-D9726C992634/0/10983designforaccessibilityguideupdated.pdf |title=Basingstoke and Deane - Designing for Accessibility |publisher=Centre for Accessible Environments |accessdate=September 2004}}</ref>
Ramps can have a maximum going of {{convert|10|m|ftin|abbr=on}}, beyond which there has to be a landing before continuing as a ramp. The maximum permissible gradient for non domestic dwellings, 1:12, applies to ramps with a going no greater than {{convert|2|m|ftin|abbr=on}}. This equates to a maximum Rise of {{convert|133|mm|in|0|abbr=on}}. The gradient of the longest permissible ramp going of {{convert|10|m|ftin|abbr=on}} must not be steeper than 1:20. This equates to a maximum Rise of {{convert|500|mm|in|0|abbr=on}}. In between these two limits of ramp goings the allowable steepest gradient varies in a graduated way. This is shown in the Building Regulations 2004 Part M on a graph from which the reader is required to interpolate the allowable gradient. Alternatively, there is a simple calculation method which gives a very accurate result. The formulae for these are <reference ODPM>: (1) TO CALCULATE THE GOING FOR A KNOWN RISE (all dimensions in mm.) Going = (Rise X 10 000) / (1000 - Rise) Note. The calculated Going is the minimum allowable for the given Rise. (2) TO CALCULATE THE RISE FROM A KNOWN GOING (all dimensions in mm) Rise = (Going x 1000) / (Going + 10 000) Note. The calculated Rise is the maximum allowable for the given Going.
In [[Hong Kong]], wheelchair ramp may not exceed a 1:12 slope for wheelchairs except in some situations under the Barrier Free Access (BFA) terms.<ref >{{cite web |url=http://www.bd.gov.hk/english/documents/code/bfa2008/Division5.pdf |title=Design Manual - Barrier Free Access 2008, Chapter 4, Division 5 - Ramps |publisher=Buildings Department, Hong Kong |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref>
In South Africa 1:12 max unless difference in level is less than 400mm in which case 1:10 max. [SANS 10400-S SS2(a)].
In Australia, the Australian Standards Council requires a wheelchair ramp to have a maximum incline of 1 in 14. This means that for every {{convert|14|m|ftin}} travelled horizontally, the ramp rises {{convert|1|m|ftin}}. The wheelchair ramp must also have a minimum width of {{convert|1|m|ftin}}.<ref >{{cite web |url=https://www.humanrights.gov.au/publications/access-guidelines-and-information |title=Access: Guidelines and information |accessdate=May 2015}}</ref>
==Vehicle ramps== [[Wheelchair accessible van|Wheelchair accessible vehicles]] may also include a ramp to facilitate entry and exit. These may be built-in or portable designs. Most major automotive companies offer rebates for portable ramps and mobility access equipment for new vehicles.
